title: Why do people study humanities? - Quora

response.answer_text: I wish I’d write an answer so beautifully elaborate and compelling that your heart melts with pleasure and your mind blooms wisdom. I’ve yet to reach such personal balance and mastery of the written word, so instead, I’d like to offer you something else, a superficial, yet humorous, I hope, explanation:  People study humanities for all sorts of reasons: “Because they’re girls and girls aren’t good at math or at tech stuff.” This is sadly a widespread stereotype so deeply embedded in modern culture that it actually affects how interested girls are in tech/math/science and how well they perform on these subjects. In fact, there’s such a connection between the two, that the moment “life-science” was cool for girls, a huge number of girls started, all of a sudden, being good at life-sciences. Somedays I wonder if this would happen should we eliminate the gender-separators in sports, you know, have women outclassing men in the same race. That would be something.Because some people absolutely love stuff that other people have no interest in, or are, perhaps, intimidated by, or can’t really find a way to understand or be good at. Stuff like topology, artificial intelligence, turing-complete programming languages, bayesian statistics, stochastic processes <insert a georgecarlinesque enumeration here>. Or mechatronics, which I’ve mentioned separately because it’s such a funky and cool word. Could you believe it, there are other people that are interested in poetry, psychology, literature, sociology, philosophy, logic, argumentation, aaah, all the “ogy” and the “ion” at the end..Because, broadly speaking, you’re dealing with people, no matter what you do, even if you study mechatronics, you’re dealing with people, you need to learn something about people in order to do your job. You need to know people have fingers before you can make a keyboard, and you need to know about how humans learn so that you can develop a keyboard people find easy to use. I could go on, but there’s not one profession in this world that isn’t, in some way, human-related, even if all you do is wipe the dust off the hdds in the data center of some corporation, those hdds still hold important stuff on them with or about people. That’s a really bad example/analogy I just gave, nobody wipes the dust off hdds in data centres, I just couldn’t go with the “you could be the janitor”, because I happen to believe that janitors are really cool, and I’d actually include one in one of my novels as a main character.Because people have a drive to look for meaning, and humanities teach you about meaning, how to see what it is, how to find it, what it’s made of etc Consider that essentially all of what we have in terms of knowledge today indirectly developed from humanities. Even more so, all of the freedoms and the liberties that you have today, you have because of humanities. Because of the art of deliberation, negotiation, strategy and manipulation, other words that end in “ation”, such as nation. Meaning is something you, I, everyone, needs. It’s this huge wordplay and irony, I suppose, though I’ll answer that later.Because they take your brain on a trip upon a magic swirling ship. I had this one interview I was supposed to talk about “what my values are”. That was horrible. Don’t get me wrong, I know what values are. I can evaluate what other people have as values and I can see what their value hierarchies, and potentially even come up with a theory as to why they ended up with such a value system, and relate that to a lot of other things. I can do a lot of things, I know a lot of things, I know a lot of words, I have the best of words. Yet I found myself not able to come up with any half-decent answer. Some days later, pondering, I realised why: I’m likely a self-denying self-actualizer that’s going through an existential crisis OR SOMETHING LIKE THAT. It’s not the vocabulary, it’s the concepts. I had the concepts to frame my inability and diagnose my issue. I still haven’t fixed that issue, though trust me, no amount of pills ever will. The only way anything but self-knowledge and exploration and love will fix my issues is if you build me a time machine and teleport MY MIND into my 3-year old body, with all the skills and memories I have today.Because humanities people rule the world. Sure, you get 400k and some other perks at facebook, fine. Not you personally, “Mann” sort of like in German, which is an awesome language. Do you think you’re happier than I know how to be? Hah, let’s not talk about me, there’s something intrinsically wrong about me, let’s talk about someone awesome, such as Dushka Zapata, she wrote a book about “How to be ferociously happy”. Do you understand, there are simply so many things you can understand in so many ways, can you, will you? Being happy, that’s something that many people, sadly, need to learn. And that’s something humanities can offer (unless you figure out a way to normalise the use of heroin). Least we forget about all the Presidents and politicians, leaders of whatever sort of company or corporation you know … etc etc It really is mostly humanities people.I’ll leave this one empty, for your own thoughts to fill:
